metadata.title: Title: Sensitivity evaluation of 2019 novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) RT-PCR 1 detection kits and strategy to reduce false negative 2 Running title: Strategy for detection of the COVID-19 patients 3

abstract.text: An ongoing outbreak of pneumonia associated with SARS-CoV-2 has now been 26 confirmed globally. In absence of effective vaccines, infection prevention and control 27 through diagnostic testing and quarantine is critical. Early detection and differential 28 diagnosis of respiratory infections increases the chances for successful control of 29 COVID-19 disease. The nucleic acid RT-PCR test is regarded as the current standard 30 for molecular diagnosis with high sensitivity. However, the highest specificity 31 confirmation target ORF1ab gene is considered to be less sensitive than other targets 32 in clinical application. In addition, a large amount of recent evidence indicates that the 33 initial missed diagnosis of asymptomatic patients with SARS-CoV-2 and discharged 34 patients with "re-examination positive" may be due to low viral load, and the ability 35 of rapid mutation of coronavirus also increases the rate of false negative results. We 36 aimed to evaluate the sensitivity of different nucleic acid detection kits so as to make 37 recommendations for the selection of validation kit, and amplify the suspicious result 38 to be reportable positive by means of simple continuous amplification, which is of 39 great significance for the prevention and control of the current epidemic and the 40 discharge criteria of low viral load patients.

body_text.text: The coronavirus that caused the outbreak was identified in the case of viral 48 pneumonia in Wuhan in 2019 [1] [2] [3] , and was named 2019-nCoV/SARS-CoV-2 by the 49 World Health Organization (WHO) [2, 4, 5] . SARS-CoV-2 belongs to the coronavirus 50 genus β and its genome is single-stranded, non-segmented positive-sense RNA [6] , 51 which is the seventh known coronavirus that can infect humans [1, 7] . Similar to other 52 pathogenic RNA viruses, the genetic material RNA is the first marker to be detected. 53 Nucleic acid detection or sequencing is currently used in conjunction with pulmonary 54 CT for clinical diagnosis of 9] . As the course of the disease progresses, 55 antibodies IgM and IgG will be produce by the human immune system. Although, 56 antibody tests play a major role in monitoring the response to future immunization 57 strategies and demonstrating previous exposure/immunity, the antibody positive rate 58 often lags behind the nucleic acid detection [10] [11] [12] , and cross-reactions existed in 59 SARS-CoV antigen with autoantibodies [13] . 60 Theoretically, fluorescence quantitative RT-PCR detection is widely used as the 61 molecular diagnosis standard for 15] . Lately, the analysis showed 62 that the pattern of viral load change in COVID-19 patients was similar to that in 63 patients with influenza, but different from that in SARS and MERS (whose viral load 64 peaked about 10 days after the onset of symptoms) [16] [17] [18] [19] . At present, a large 65 number of rapid gene detection technologies have been developed in succession, 66 which has great value for the screening of potential infectors and virus detection. 67 However, with too much emphasis on the "fast" characteristic, it is bound to cause a 68 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. [21, 22] , the low load virus will still lead to false negative or 73 spontaneous negative signals of thermostatic technology.

In COVID-19 patients, RT-PCR detection could be positive as early as one day 75 before the onset of symptoms, while most COVID-19 patients cannot be detected 76 before premorbid because of the low copy number of the virus [2, [7, 17, 23] . In 77 addition, some discharged patients appearing "re-examination positive" situation is 78 also because of the persistence of a small number of viruses. Unfortunately, the 79 positive rate of RT-PCR detection of SARS-CoV-2 is only 30%-50% at present [24, 25] 80 due to improper sample collection, storage, and error detection [26] . Furthermore, 81 once the target gene mutated or deleted, the test results will be invalid [27, 28] .

RT-PCR nucleic acid detection not only has a high false negative rate [29] , but also 83 has a low sensitivity [30] . Currently, the approved nucleic acid detection kits of the 84 SARS-CoV-2 genome are based on the most conserved and specific open reading 85 frame 1ab (ORF1ab), Envelope protein (E) and nucleocapsid protein (N) [6, 31, 32] .

Athough ORF1ab is the highest specificity confirmation target gene, but is considered 87 to be less sensitive than other targets in clinical application [33] , so does the pattern of 88 ORF1ab positive reports cause missed tests? Is it feasible to report based on positive 89 N or E genes? Clinically, it is recommended that samples with suspicious results or 90 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

However, what is the basis for choosing the validation kit? This is a 92 problem that needs to be solved. And 108 the two swabs from nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal were inserted into one sterile 109 tube containing 3 ml of Virus preservation solution. FIGREF0.text: from January to February 2020, in Jinan Central Hospital Affiliated to 98 Shandong University and Jinan Infectious Disease Hospital, Shandong University, 99 which were diagnosed by clinical symptoms, lung CT and nucleic acid test. And 100 100 suspected cases were collected in the first institution listed above, which had 101 symptoms of fever, dry cough and pneumonia image. This research was approved by 102 the Ethics Commission of Jinan Central Hospital and with informed consent of the 103 patient.

FIGREF1.text: oropharyngeal swab specimens were collected with synthetic 106 fiber swabs under the guideline of the Chinese Centre for Disease Control and107

FIGREF2.text: RNA was extracted using magnetic bead method strictly according to the 115 instructions of Nucleic acid extraction kit (Shanghai Zhijiang Biotechnology Co., Ltd, 116 Shanghai, China). The RNA samples were diluted with RNA extract from 117 nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swab of negative patients for detecting by 118 RT-PCR. 119 Laboratory quality-control 120 Acceptable specimens are respiratory and serum specimens, the former including: 121 nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swabs, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, tracheal 122 aspirates and sputum. Cotton swab heads are not allowed for swab specimens.123 Specimens should not be stored for more than 72 hours at 4℃. Cross-reactive 124 experiments should be performed to verify the specificity (Supplemental table 1). 125 Positive control and negative control should be tested at the same time as all samples. 126 The fluorescence amplification curve of negative control should not exceed the 127 threshold. The CT value of all targets in the positive control should be within the 128 expected range. The detection kit should contain the internal target gene, and the 129 amplification curve should exceed the threshold line.

FIGREF3.text: different amplification kits were selected with three different primers and 132 probes sources, among which one was from China's CDC, two was from the World 133 Health Organization (WHO) [6], and the other two were self-designed by the kit 134 manufacturer. Information for the five amplification kits was shown in table 1. Each 135 kit contained 25 μl of reaction system including 5μl of RNA template. The 136 amplification was operated separately according to the instructions of kits. The 137 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF4.text: 149swab samples from a confirmed positive patient. After RNA extraction, the RNA was 150 diluted according to the following proportion gradient: 160, and 1:320. Then, RT-PCR results showed that the dilution titer of ORF1ab was 152 the highest in the kit-1 (Figure 1A), indicating that the kit-1 was the most sensitive to 153 SARS-CoV-2, followed by the kit-2. In addition, the CT value of the amplification 154 curve was found to be positively correlated with the dilution titer (Figure 1B). The Ct 155 values of ORF1ab gene and N gene in kit-1 were still within the reportable interval at 156 1:20 and 1:160 dilution respectively, while reached the detection suspicious region in 157 kit-2 at 1:5 and 1:40 dilution titer.158Then, if the N gene or E gene is positive when ORF1ab gene is negative, how to 159 judge the result and how to select the validation kit? For example, three cases were 160 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF5.text: a suspicious region with kit 2, it can be converted to positive after verification 163 with kit 1; 3. When N gene was negative with kit 2, it can be converted to positive 164 after verification with kit 1. For the sake of further verify the sensitivity, another 9 165 positive samples were enrolled. The positive RNA extract was first quantified by 166 digital PCR and then diluted to the same initial concentration. The results showed that 167 ORF1ab gene can still be reported as positive at 1:10 dilution and the N gene even at 168 1:40 dilution (Figure. 1D) with kit-1, while they exceeded the detection line at 1:5 and 169 1:20 respectively with kit-2. Hence, we have reasons to believe that kit-1 has the 170 highest sensitivity through the verification of multiple positive samples.

FIGREF6.text: choosing a more sensitive kit for validation, is there an easier method to 174 increase the positive detection rate? First, the RT-PCR products of the above diluted 175 samples in the suspicious range were amplified for another 40 cycles, and found that 176 for the samples with dilution gradients of 1:10 and 1:20, the ORF1ab and N genes 177 with large original amplified Ct values were expanded to the positive reportable 178 region, while other dilution gradients only with N or E genes were significantly 179 amplified (figure. 2A). Moreover, 100 patients with clinical fever and dry cough who180

FIGREF7.text: were re-amplified to be positive by continuous amplification (Figure.

FIGREF8.text: acid testing and found that the sample inside the mask of one 185 patient was weakly positive, which could be reported as positive after another 186 re-amplification (Figure 2C). Through analysis, we found that each target gene could 187 reach the amplification plateau by adding another 30 cycles. In addition, we tried to 188 add the initial RT-PCR amplification products of positive patients into a new 189 amplification reaction system, and found that the results were not reliable (Data not 190 shown).

FIGREF9.text: reduce false negatives of SARS-CoV-2 193 Above all, we suggest that the laboratory must evaluate the sensitivity of detection 194 kits first. If the laboratory can only select two kits, the selection strategy from 195 detection to validation kit should be based on its sensitivity from low to high. In other 196 words, the sensitivity of the validation kit must be higher than that of the test kit, 197 which is of great significance to the suspected re-examination samples and the 198 discharge criteria of patients. Moreover, for these specimens with the suspicious 199 interval region or single channel positive results, the continuous amplification can be 200 used to increase the detection rate of low viral load specimens and greatly reduce the 201 false negative rate of SARS-CoV-2.

FIGREF11.text: COVID-19 had surpassed 3000,000 with more than 210,000 deaths. With an 207 increasing number of potential cases emerge, the SARS-CoV-2 poses a major threat to 208 global public health[34]. A greater number of diagnostic tools have been developed 209 such as virus isolation, PCR-based assays, IHC, and antibody assays, which are 210 currently in place across different diagnostic laboratories around the world[35, 36]. 211 Although, RT-PCR is challenged by the "false negative" results[37], in view of the 212 past major epidemic outbreaks [38], RT-PCR is still the preferred detection method, 213 and how to ensure the accuracy of nucleic acid test results is the currently facing 214 problem. In this study, we aimed to evaluate the sensitivity of different RT-PCR kits 215 for COVID-19 diagnosis. 216 Different target genes of SARS-CoV-2 were used in countries 217 (https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/technical-guidance/laboratory-guidance), while some 218 scholars believe that the detection of N gene is an accurate, rapid, early and simple 219 diagnostic method for COVID-19[39]. Then, under the current circumstance, can the 220 single target N or double targets N and E be judged as positive for SARS-CoV-2? An 221 increasing number of articles showed that the SARS-CoV-2 is undergoing rapid 222 mutation [40, 41]. Ninety-three mutations were found over the entire genomes of 223 SARS-CoV-2 [42] with twenty-nine missense mutations in the ORF1ab region and 224 four in the N region (table1). Fortunately, through gene comparison on BLAST, the 225 primer or probe sequences published by CDC and WHO were not in these mutation 226 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF12.text: 227 can enhances the transcription of the downstream N gene[28] which may increase the 228 false negative detection rate of SARS-CoV-2. Thus, attentions should be paid to the 229 abnormally amplified N gene in clinical detection. The latest clinical research has 230 revealed that the prevalence of SARS-CoV-2 among patients with influenza like 231 illnesses reached 5% in Los Angeles medical center[43]. Due to the difficulty to 232 distinguish the mild COVID-19 with influenza virus [44-46], China CDC has made it 233 clearly that influenza testing should be combined with SARS-CoV-2 testing [47]. 234 Although the detection rate of viral nucleic acid is closely related to the course of 235 viral infection, which is not completely clear and the optimal sampling time is 236 uncertain, so it is likely that the period of high viral load in the nasopharyngeal swab 237 samples will be missed, resulting in false negatives[48]. The nasopharyngeal swabs 238 are the most common samples for SARS-CoV-2 detection, while the stool samples are 239 reported as a good test target during treatment recently[49], and the positive fecal 240 nucleic acid has an important correlation with the development of the patient's disease 241 course, which may become an important indicator for the evaluation of therapeutic 242 efficacy and discharge criteria. 243 As with all viral nucleic acid testing projects, the RT-PCR results of SARS-CoV-2 244 are affected by various factors including before, during and after detection, thus 245 sufficient laboratory quality-control measures should be taken. Although, the 246 continuous amplification and other detection methods of SARS-CoV do exhibit false 247 positive results [50, 51], the continuous amplification is recommend to use only when 248 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF14.text: Sensitivity evaluation of SARS-CoV-2 detection kits. (A) Gradient dilution 384 experiments showed that different kits have different sensitivity. (B) Ct value of different target genes 385 were positively correlated with the dilution concentration. (C) Selection of test kit and validation kit.386 (D) CDC kit has the highest sensitivity through the verification of multiple positive samples. Strategies to reduce false negatives of SARS-CoV-2. (A) Continuous 388 amplification of PCR products for gradient dilution samples. (B) Continuous amplification of PCR 389 products for the nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal swab specimens of clinical fever patients. (C) 390 Continuous amplification of PCR products for the environmental samples of 3 positive patients. The 391 specimen with a cycle threshold value of target genes above the baseline is interpreted as positive for 392 SARS-CoV-2; those under, negative. Kit 1 was used for figure 2A and B, while kit 2 for figure 2C.

More importantly, we also believe that antibody test and nucleic acid test should complement each other to improve the diagnosis effect, especially to screen asymptomatic patients better, so as to reduce the detection "false negative" phenomenon of "false recovered patients" or premorbid patients with low virus latency.Ethics approval and consent to participateThis study was undertaken with the approval of the Jinan Central Hospital Affiliated 257 to Shandong University Ethics Service Committee.
